question: What is MCP in simple terms?
answer: MCP lets AI access your files, databases, and tools directly instead of you copy-pasting everything. Like giving AI "hands" to reach your data.

question: Do I need to be technical to use MCP?
answer: No. The masterclass covers GUI tools (Dockmaster, Toolbase) that make installation easy. No coding required.

question: Which AI tools support MCP?
answer: Claude Desktop, Claude Web (with extension), Claude Code, Cline, Cursor, VSCode with Copilot, Windsurf, and growing. OpenAI announced ChatGPT support in March 2025.

question: Can I use MCP with my Obsidian notes?
answer: Yes! Demo 1 shows exactly this. AI reads your Obsidian vault directly.

question: Is MCP secure?
answer: MCP servers run locally on your machine. Claude Desktop requires user confirmation for sensitive operations. Masterclass covers security considerations in depth.

question: Where do I find MCP servers?
answer: Multiple directories covered: Smithery, official repos, community directories. Masterclass provides complete resource list.

question: How do I install MCP servers?
answer: Multiple methods: GUI tools (easiest), command line, npm. Masterclass demonstrates all approaches.

question: Can MCP search the web?
answer: Yes! Demo 3 shows Brave Search integration. Many search providers available.

question: Can AI control my browser?
answer: Yes! Demo 4 shows browser control. Navigate sites, extract data, fill forms.

question: Will MCP work with future AI tools?
answer: Yes. MCP is an open standard. OpenAI announced support for ChatGPT and their AI Agents SDK.

question: Is this included in any bundles?
answer: Yes - included free with: Knowii Community "Knowledge Builder" tier (€19.99/month), Knowii Community "Knowledge Master" tier (€39.99/month), Knowledge Worker Kit (€149.99 one-time)

question: Is this still relevant? MCP is from November 2024.
answer: Very relevant! MCP is growing rapidly. OpenAI just added support (March 2025). Official registry coming. This is the BEGINNING of MCP adoption.
